Mattias Fagerlund wrote:

>That's such a stellar quote "day trader[s]...may loose money more often
>and in predictable ways", I love that ;)
>  
>
That was the diplomatic way of stating what I was *actually* thinking :)

On the other hand day-traders are dealing directly with their own money 
and livelihoods, whereas I would guess city traders have a more removed, 
abstract approach to trading because they presumably deal with much 
larger amounts of money which isn't theirs. So maybe institutions loose 
more money? Also, if some of these big players are using AI agents then 
these agents may themselves have weak points in their strategies that 
can be indirectly exploited.

>I have a feeling that day traders are more gamblers than intra day
>traders. The question is if that makes them more or less predictable. 
>  
>
It probably makes them more random, but like I say, there may be some 
population dynamics mixed in with the noise.

>Reminds me of a funny fact, most people assume that straight men have more
>sexual partners, on average, than straight women. This is patently not
>true (possibly slightly true because there are more women than men). Why
>MUST it be untrue? Because for each man that has a partner, there's a
>woman that has one too.
>  
>
Ok this *really is* off topic. All I will say is this - your logic does 
not take homosexuals into account.

Moving quickly on.... :)

>The reason I mention this is that while your quote is true, the opposite
>is surely also true, since as money is lost, it's mostly gained by someone
>else. On average, day traders come out about even - commission + the
>general trend. But it's probably safe to bet that there's a great herd of
>losing day traders and a few winning ones. 
>  
>
On average they may be loosing to city traders, or vice versa.

>Most importantly, there's more movement in the day market than in the
>intra day.
>
Many smaller movements but not necessarily a larger movement of funds. 
The main idea to take on board is that inter and intraday trading are 
probably distinct enough to warrant their treatment as seperate systems 
that can be exploited in different ways.

>>It depends how you are interpreting your output. You say >0.5 indicates
>>buy and <0.5 indicates sell. So presumbaly you consider anything within
>>magnitude 0.5 to be a hold signal? 
>>    
>>
>
>Sorry, I meant >=0.5, but _exactly_ 0.5 (with double precision) is a very
>rare occurance indeed. I don't have a hold signal, though I might add a
>band for that. 
>
Ah, that's what I was getting at, I assumed anything within -0.5 >= x <= 
0.5 would be a hold signal.

>On the other hand, if the system wants to signal hold, it
>has a parameter for "Currently Owning", which it can use to hold (strong
>influence from "Currently Owning" tends to reinforce the current
>owning/not owning position).
>  
>
Oh ok, so you neywork is really saying - "you should own this". You can 
take this signal to mean 'buy' if you don't already own, or 'hold' if 
you do. Is that right? I still think it would be nice to have the 
network give a seperate confidence output, you can then interpret low 
confidence as an indication for human intervention if you own a lot of 
that stock - you probably want to sell if you don't have any confidence 
in what is happening, otherwise you may as well spend the money on 
random bets on the horses!

Colin
